title: Erdős Problem #60: Supersaturation of 4-Cycles
description: Does every graph on n vertices with > ex(n; C_4) edges contain Ω(n^{1/2}) copies of C_4? OPEN problem.

overview.historicalContext: This is a supersaturation problem conjectured by Erdős and Simonovits. Once a graph exceeds the Turán number ex(n; C_4), it must contain at least one 4-cycle. The question asks for a quantitative bound: how many 4-cycles are forced? The conjecture is that at least Ω(n^{1/2}) copies appear. Remarkably, Erdős and Simonovits couldn't even prove that ≥ 2 copies are guaranteed.
overview.problemStatement: Does every graph on n vertices with > ex(n; C_4) edges contain ≫ n^{1/2} many copies of C_4?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines 4-cycle copies as ordered 4-tuples, the Turán number ex(n; C_4) with its asymptotic bounds, and the supersaturation conjecture. Partial results (He-Ma-Yang 2021 for projective plane orders) are axiomatized. The two-copies conjecture is stated as a weaker open problem.
keyInsights: Projective plane polarity graphs achieve the Turán number exactly
He-Ma-Yang (2021): Conjecture holds for n = q² + q + 1, q even
Even proving ≥ 2 copies are guaranteed remains open
General Erdős-Simonovits supersaturation gives some (weaker) bound

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #60, an OPEN supersaturation problem asking whether exceeding ex(n; C_4) forces Ω(n^{1/2}) copies of C_4. The conjecture remains unproven in general, with partial results for projective plane orders (He-Ma-Yang 2021).
conclusion.implications: Supersaturation problems quantify how 'far' a graph is from being extremal. For C_4, the conjectured n^{1/2} bound would be tight: polarity graphs show you can be arbitrarily close to ex(n; C_4) with zero 4-cycles.
openQuestions: Prove the full Ω(n^{1/2}) bound for all n
Determine the exact constant in the lower bound
Extend He-Ma-Yang to all projective plane orders
